<answer>



I used to have a great time on Bonfire Night with my family as a child.



The best memories I have are of barbecued sausages and burgers with lots of onion!



We used to really enjoy making the Guy together. I'd ask all my neighbours for a small piece to make the Guy with before they'd all come over for the bonfire night gathering at mum and dads!



We also used to have toffee apples, which I'd help mum to make. She'd mix up the toffee and I'd pop the apples in!



A barbecue is always good at Bonfire Night-and roast potatoes that have been slightly cooled so you can eat them! YUM!!



</answer>

<answer>



Google homemade gifts and a bunch of sites will come up with great ideas for you to choose from.



You could also go to Michael's or another craft store and buy some ceramics, boxes, etc.  to paint.  They will also have a lot of other crafts that you can choose from. Homemade Chocolate-Go to Michael's, WalMart, or candy supply store and choose the molds that you want to buy and pick up the chocolate and whatever fillings you may want.  Melt the chocolate in a double boiler or in the microwave.  If you do it in the microwave put it in for about 20 seconds stir and repeat until completely melted.  Make sure you stir the bottom so it doesn't burn.  Then pour into your molds and place in the Freezer.  when the mold is cloudy take it out and flip them over and shake gently.  If they don't come out put them back into the freezer.



</answer>

<answer>



have you tried to search it on yahoo or google? I know personally I plan to make blankets... Purchase 2 pieces of fleece.. I try to buy 2 different pieces for example one piece has puppies on it the other side is just plain purple... the size of the fabric should be 1 yard and a half each....... place the two pieces on top of one another and cut slits alll the way around the edges.. this gives it a fringe effect.... then tie the finge pieces together and you have a nice blanket...



see this website for a picture and for more thorough directions

<answer>



There are four conditions any one of them, will open up your books and the pens will start to write your good or bad deeds that you commit...



If you have experienced any one of them.. before whatever you did. You can still repent Allah is most merciful.



"But verily thy Lord,- to those who do wrong in ignorance, but who thereafter repent and make amends,- thy Lord, after all this, is Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful." )But verily thy Lord,- to those who do wrong in ignorance, but who thereafter repent and make amends,- thy Lord, after all this, is Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful. (16:119)



"But those who do wrong but repent thereafter and (truly) believe,- verily thy Lord is thereafter Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful." (7:153)
_________________________________
"Puberty is known in Islamic law as al-bulugh, or Tamyeez, (coming of age as a man and woman). There are three signs of puberty (bulugh):



1. Discharging semen as a result of wet dreams, known as inzaalul-manyyi. Allah (SWT) states: "But when the children among you come of age, let them also ask for permission, as do those senior to them in age..." (Al-Qur'an, 24-59)



In a hadith, the Messenger of Allah (saas) said: "Friday bath (ghuslul-Jum'ah) is mandatory upon anyone who has experienced a wet dream." (Bukhari/Muslim) The point in this hadith is that Islamic obligations are not incumbent on anyone until they reach the age of bulugh.



2. Appearance of hair around the pubic area is another sign of puberty. If a person sees that even without wet dreams, he or she has attained puberty. This may happen at the age of thirteen or fourteen, and parents should inform girls and boys about these signs.



3. Reaching 15 years of age: When the person reaches 15, he or she is a man or a woman, and anything that is obligatory on a man or woman is obligatory on him or her from that time on.



In a hadith reported by Abdullah Bin Umar (raa), he said: "My parents brought me to the Messenger of Allah on the eve of the Uhud Campaign and I was fourteen years old, so the Prophet (saas) did not enlist me in fighting." But a year later in the Campaign of Al-Khandaqq, I was fifteen, so this time the Prophet (saas) enlisted me in combat." (Muslim)



This hadith indicates the age of 15 is the legal age for a Muslim boy or girl to be responsible for his or her religion as well as worldly responsibilities. Some of us who reside in the western world, seem to think adulthood depends on State laws. In some states it is 18, while in others it is 19, or 21, and so on. This is a very serious mistake, as the juvenile will reach puberty (bulugh) and adulthood, but go on without observing his or her Islamic duties, such as Salat, fasting, or being restrained from that which is prohibited.
Puberty - Girls



Girls reach puberty and adulthood when they experience the above three signs. However, they have a fourth sign, that is, menstruation (hayd). Whenever a girl experiences it, she is a woman even if she is 12 years old. At that time, the Qalam, the pen of responsibilities, begins to flow and to record the deeds of the servant, good or bad. It is interesting that in the western world the case is the reverse. You see, when a juvenile reaches the age of puberty in Al-Islam he or she should be careful about anything he or she does or says. On the contrary, in the West when the person comes of age, he or she is allowed to do things which are detrimental to his or her well being. They are licensed to read, watch, and listen to so- called adult material, as if when one is an adult it is time to be irresponsible.



Indeed, if puberty is attained during the days of Ramadan, say at midday, and the young person is fasting, he or she should continue his or her fasting and there will be no obligation on him or her to make up the fast. If he was not fasting, it is incumbent upon him to observe the rest of the day in fasting, because he has become an adult upon whom Islamic rites are obligatory. Girls in menstruation can't observe half day, nor should they make that half day up."



Source(s):



http://www.usc.edu/dept/MSA/fundamentals...



</answer>

There are 3 reasons for starting buying presents beforehand:
1) You don't involve yourself into Christmas presents rush
2) Some things may cost less now than right before Christmas
3) If you see a really good present now, there is no guarantee that it would be available before Christmas.

<question from>



Slave to Allah (Muslimah)
Member since: 02 March 2008
Total points: 2183 (Level 3)

</question from>



<question>



WHO WERE RESPONSIBLE IN KILLING OF KARBALÂ?



It should be borne in mind that this tragedy did not take place all of a sudden like a bolt from the blue. It was in fact the manifestation of the plot of Sabayees which had claimed the life of Uthman , the third Caliph and the son-in-law of the Prophet



Twenty- five years earlier. Caliph Uthman’s martyrdom took place on 18th of Dhu Al-Hajj, 36 A.H.



In the next twenty years which include the reigns of Omar and Uthman , the second and third Caliph of Islaam, many more countries were conquered under the banner of Islaam and the Muslim empire extended over a vast expanse of the globe, comprising Iraq, Syria, Iran on one side and a large part of North Africa including Egypt and Morocco on the other. But the historical process has its immutable laws. As the Revolution of the Prophet  was challenged by the reactionary movements on the Arab land, the same happened with the conquests of those two Caliphs. The first target of these reactionaries was the person of Omar who was assassinated by Abu Luloo Feroze, a Parsi slave from Iran. It was purely an Iranian plot hatched by Hurmuzan, an Iranian general, who thought that if Omar was removed from the scene, the empire of Islaam would fall like a house of cards. But by the grace of Allah (SWT), it survived the calamity. Abdullah Ibn Saba, a Jew from Yemen, under the garb of a Muslim, took his sojourn at Madeenah. He had all the trappings of an expert plotter and the Jewish genius at intrigues, an attribute of his clan. He planted subversive ideas among the people. He pleaded for the usurped rights of the house of the Prophet  Muhammad , carried out a propaganda campaign against Caliph Uthman and incited the people to revolt. He declared Ali to be the rightful successor to the Prophet Muhammad  and dubbed Uthman  as a usurper. He told people that every Prophet has a wasee and Ali is the wasee of Prophet Mohammad and, therefore, entitled to be the caliph after the Prophet. He also preached the divinity of Ali , thus striking at  Tauheed, the very root of Islaam. The Iranians, who had embraced Islaam only a few years before, were taken in by this propaganda because they had a long history of kingship and hero-worship. They were familiar with the divine rights of kings, and hero-worship was diffused in their blood. They readily accepted these ideas and became their champions. Similarly Abdullah Ibn Saba floated another viewpoint related to the second appearance of Prophet Isa (AS). He argued that Prophet Muhammad , who is the best amongst the prophets of Allaah (SWT), would also appear with Christ, for the contrary would imply that he is inferior to Prophet Isa (AS). This was the same argument used by the Qadianis in later years, who invented the notion of the death and burial of Prophet Isa (AS) in Kashmir. They argued that it was illogical for Prophet Muhammad to have died and for Prophet Isa (AS) to be alive in the heaven. Unsophisticated and illiterate Muslims saw a point of adoration in it for Prophet Muhammad and fell an easy prey to that sort of propaganda.



Abdullah Ibn Saba travelled all over the Muslim lands and set up his propaganda centers at Basra and Kufa, but his attempts failed in Damascus. Then he went to Egypt where he formed a party of his supporters. Consequently, the last two years of Caliph Uthman’s reign were filled with machinations, intrigue, and turmoil all over Muslim territories. It culminated in the most unjustified murder (martyrdom) of Caliph Uthman who was the ruler of a vast empire and had tens of thousands of soldiers under his command but refused to shed the blood of Muslims in self-protection. Governors of provinces from all over the empire besought the Caliph to allow them to send troops to quell the uprising and to protect his person from the rebels who had surrounded his residence, but he remained strict and steadfast in his decision. It is perhaps a unique and unprecedented episode in the entire history of mankind that a very powerful man, like the Caliph Uthman , refused to use authority for his personal safety and let himself be assassinated. May Allah (SWT) shower His blessings on him.



The murder of Habeel (son of Adam) by his brother Qabeel is perhaps an incident comparable to Caliph Uthman’s assassination. When Qabeel declared his intention to kill Habeel, the latter announced his resolve, in the words of the Qur'ân:



Even if thou stretch out thy hand against me, I shall not stretch out my hand against thee to kill thee; lo! I fear Allah the Lord of the worlds. (Al-Ma’ida 5:28)



</question>

<question>



Gift for bedridden grandma?



Any ideas for a special and suitable gift for a bedridden elderly person?



My grandparents raised me, and we were really close. I now live in another city and don't see her often. She first broke *both* of her hips (she is really tiny and fragile) and then had a stroke (DVT clot) from being bedridden. Her vision is very poor. She's really gone downhill and this may be our last Christmas together.



She wears compression boots and hospital gowns, so clothing, robes, slippers, etc is not a good option. The nurses have little time to spend with her, so things like lotions and creams probably won't get used/applied. Her vision is poor, and the nurses never put on her glasses, so books and videos are out. She has poor manual dexterity and movement because of the stroke, so crafts, etc. are out. See why I'm stumped!



I was thinking perhaps a musical ornament that I can ask the nurses to wind up or turn out. Thankfully, her hearing is the one thing that is OK.



Is there anyone out there who can help? I want to make her last bits of time her meaningful. I am the only grandchild (!) on that side of the family, and my grandparents raised me for most of my years, so we were very close.

<answer>



It depends. Do you consider lying to your child a sin?



Personally, I am not telling my kids about Santa. Not because of religious reasons, but because I think it's silly to tell our kids that a fat man rides around on a sleigh giving buckets of presents to "good" (AKA well off) kids around the world in a timeframe of 24 hours.



Any kid with half a brain should be able to see through this, and I'd just feel stupid telling this story with a straight face. There are more important lessons to be taught about Christmas. Tell the kid about the *real* St. Nick....



Also, if you're celebrating Christmas, you might want to tell them about Jesus. Remember him? The concept around which this holiday was created? You don't have to be religious to celebrate winter holidays, but please, make the holidays *meaningful* at least.  Educate your kids. Make them volunteer by visiting homeless shelter with presents or nursing homes with lonely residents who have no one to share the holidays with.



So what if people disagree. So sue me.



Sorry if this comes off as hostile. I don't mean to be, I just want people to remember what Christmas is really about, and not just about wanting heaps and heaps of presents. In my opinion, one meaningful gift and kind words to another person means more than $3000 worth of gifts ever could.



Source(s):

<answer>



The old tradition's over isn't it?
The twelve days of Christmas (as in "A partridge in a pear tree" etc.)
were from Christmas Eve til January 6th.



And, as a child, bringing in and decorating the Christmas tree on Christmas Eve was absolutely the done thing, and a great thrill.



I still hold on to not a thing before December the 1st, and I'm the last amongst those around me.



I can understand those facing ice and snow by Christmas wanting to get them up, unlit, early on.
Not a problem, here on Bodmin Moor.



(but of course, no-one here keeps their decorations up till January 6th any more, except for massive outdoor displays: I can understand those facing ice and snow by Christmas wanting to get them up, unlit, early on.  And waiting til better weather to take them down.)



But here, some shops had Christmas goods out two weeks ago, and last week I heard my first Christmas music (A singing, animated, Santa).  When it starts that early the cheer and the magic has evaporated by the time Christmas (finally!) arrives.



If we can't get back to Christmas Eve, an embargo until December the first for all would be good. Four weeks of Christmas rather than twelve days, that I could manage.



</answer>

<question from>



titch482...
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 397 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



When does christmas officially start?



so i obviously know when christmas day is, but i'm wondering when it actually starts? is it like in the song 'the 12 days of christmas'?



</question>



<answer from>



mint
Member since: 04 September 2006
Total points: 375 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Contrary to some popular belief, the Twelve Days of Christmas are not the 12 days before Christmas.  Rather, the Twelve Days of Christmas are the 12 days from December 26 (St. Stephen's Day) to the Feast of Epiphany on January 6.



In some cultures, Christmas celebrations take place on December 25th; while in others, like Armenians, Christmas celebrations take place on January 6th.  [Armenia is the first Christian nation.]



</answer>



<asker's comment>



only answer is the best answer!!



</asker's comment>

My favourite thing about christmas is this:
On christmas eve when everyone has gone to bed, I go and sit in the room with the tree, with just the lights on, the flickering of the flames from the fire lending a glow to the room.  I sit there with a big mug of hot chocolate with a little bit of something alcoholic in it and I curl up by myself on the sofa and I just sit and smile and look at the christmas tree twinkling away in the corner (we always have the biggest we can get - about 7ft) with all the presents underneath. <answer>



1. Global/International sighting
2. Local sighting
3. Calculated method



Global sighting is to be able to sight the moon anywhere in the world, and they declared eid Tuesday inshallah because of sighting the moon in several countries, and some countries already prayed eid prayer by now. [due to the general command of the prophet to all Muslim to sight the moon, and doesn't say in specific area of Muslims. In fact prophet accepted sighting of other towns and city when there was a communication]



Local sighting in Canada(so I am assuming same for USA) started fasting september 2nd and therefore cannot have eid on Tuesday (or else they'd have 28 days of Ramadan instead of 29/30). It is either Wednesday or Thursday for them. They are waiting to sight the moon Tuesday night, if they don't sight it, the month of Ramadan would complete with 30 days (meaning eid on Thursday).



Calculated method is a new system introduced in the religion, and mainly ISNA and those masaajid connected with them is following this method. They declared eid to be on Wednesday loooong time back. It is prohibited to use scientific calculation because of the saying of the prophet:
"We are an illiterate nation. We do not use astronomical writing or computation [for our fasting]. A month is so and so (and he pointed with his hands three times, folding the thumb on the third time, meaning twenty-nine days) or so and so (and he pointed with his hands three times, meaning thirty days)" [Bukhaaree and Muslim and Abu Daawood].



</answer>

<answer>



Allah (S.W.T.) describes the qualities of a good Muslim in the following verses of Holy Quran.



1. Those who offer their Salat (prayers) with all solemnity and full submissiveness. (Quran-2:23 Surah Al-Mu'minun)
2. And those who turn away from Al-Laghw (dirty, false, evil, vain talk, falsehood, and all that Allah as forbidden. (Quran-3:23).
3. And those who pay the Zakat. (Quran-4-23)
4. And those who guard their chastity (i.e. private parts from illegal sexual acts). (Quran-5:23).
5. Those who are faithfully true to their Amanat (all the duties which Allah has ordained, honesty, moral responsibility and trusts) and to their covenants; (Quran-8:23).
6. And those who strictly guard their (five compulsory congregational) Salawat (prayers) at their fixed stated hours. Quran-9:23).
7. And the (faithful) slaves of the Most Gracious (Allah) are those who walk on the earth in humility and sedateness, and when the foolish address them (with bad words) they reply back with mild words of gentleness. (Quran: 63:25).
8. And those who spend the night in worship of their Lord, postrate and standing. (Quran-64:25).
9. And those who say: "Our Lord! Avert from us the torment of Hell.  Verily its torment is ever an inseparable, permanent punishment. (Quran-65:25).
10. And those who, when they spend, are neither extravagant nor niggardly, but hold a medium (way) between those (extremes). Quran-67:25)
11. And those who invoke not any other ilah (god) along with Allah, nor kill such person as Allah has forbidden, except for just cause, nor commit illegal sexual intercourse -- and whoever does this shall receive the punishment.  Quran-68:25).
12. And those who do not bear witness to falsehood, and if they pass some evil play or evil talk, they pass by it with dignity. (Quran-72:25).
13. And those who, when they are reminded of the Ayat (proofs, evidences, verses, lessons, signs, revelations etc.) of their Lord, fall not deaf and blind thereat.



Those who do not have or lacking in these qualities are not good Muslims.



Source(s):



Mohammedali Basheer.



</answer>

<answer>



Allah (S.W.T.) describes the qualities of a good Muslim in the following verses of Holy Quran.



1. Those who offer their Salat (prayers) with all solemnity and full submissiveness. (Quran-2:23 Surah Al-Mu'minun)
2. And those who turn away from Al-Laghw (dirty, false, evil, vain talk, falsehood, and all that Allah as forbidden. (Quran-3:23).
3. And those who pay the Zakat. (Quran-4-23)
4. And those who guard their chastity (i.e. private parts from illegal sexual acts). (Quran-5:23).
5. Those who are faithfully true to their Amanat (all the duties which Allah has ordained, honesty, moral responsibility and trusts) and to their covenants; (Quran-8:23).
6. And those who strictly guard their (five compulsory congregational) Salawat (prayers) at their fixed stated hours. Quran-9:23).
7. And the (faithful) slaves of the Most Gracious (Allah) are those who walk on the earth in humility and sedateness, and when the foolish address them (with bad words) they reply back with mild words of gentleness. (Quran: 63:25).
8. And those who spend the night in worship of their Lord, postrate and standing. (Quran-64:25).
9. And those who say: "Our Lord! Avert from us the torment of Hell.  Verily its torment is ever an inseparable, permanent punishment. (Quran-65:25).
10. And those who, when they spend, are neither extravagant nor niggardly, but hold a medium (way) between those (extremes). Quran-67:25)
11. And those who invoke not any other ilah (god) along with Allah, nor kill such person as Allah has forbidden, except for just cause, nor commit illegal sexual intercourse -- and whoever does this shall receive the punishment.  Quran-68:25).
12. And those who do not bear witness to falsehood, and if they pass some evil play or evil talk, they pass by it with dignity. (Quran-72:25).
13. And those who, when they are reminded of the Ayat (proofs, evidences, verses, lessons, signs, revelations etc.) of their Lord, fall not deaf and blind thereat.



Those who do not have or lacking in these qualities are not good Muslims.



Source(s):



Mohammedali Basheer.



</answer>

<question>



Do you let your kids believe in Santa?



I grew up believing in Santa, the tooth fairy and the Easter bunny.



But as we became parents for the first time, my husband and I decided that we wouldn't have our children believe in those characters.  We feel like we would be lying to our children.  A "little white lie" is the same as a regular lie.



I know there are those who believe differently than me and I can respect that.  So no being mean please. :-(



Just want to see what others have to say :-)



</question>



<answer from>



Sola Scriptura
Member since: 21 September 2008
Total points: 306 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Absolutely not!  :)  I'm with you - it is still lying.  I never believed in Santa growing up but Christmases were just as fun.  My Mom told us, "I will never lie to you" and we grew up knowing we could trust her implicitly.  She would not always agree to answer our questions, or she would gear her answers to our ages, but she NEVER lied to us and I am sooo grateful.  It would have been devastating to me to learn that the one person I trusted most in the world had lied to me.



We have never lied that way to our children and they have never felt deprived.  Remember, too, if you are Christians, that Santa can be confusing to a young child.  Afterall, supposedly "he knows when you are sleeping; he knows when you're awake.  He knows if you've been bad or good - so be good for goodness sake!"  Sounds an awful like Jesus knowing everything, too.



Good for you and your husband for making such a wise choice.  I hope you stick to it.  Your pay-off will be in having a child who knows that Mommy and  Daddy are completely trustworthy - even in the little things.



</answer>

Thanks to everyone!!



</asker's comment>

<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I would create a few games at home - I think trick or treating has lost it's charm (in the UK that is) and it's not ideal for small kids.

Bobbing for apples - Maybe fill your washing up bowl with water and put some apples in it



Bake cookies and decorate them together halloween style with sweets

Dress up together as monsters (doesn't have to be expensive) can be done with household items and clothing, e.g. bin liners, marigolds, old clothes, saucepans for hats, card and paper to make masks.

Read him a kids halloween story under his bed sheets with a torch.



</answer>

<answer>



Buy a pumpkin and carve it. Let your child help you empty the contents.

Buy 'scary' sweets and make wee cupcakes with them.

If you are into decorating the house for Halloween, get your child to help you.

Play games like hide and seek.

Get them to help in choosing a costume and making it.

See if there are children's books catered towards Halloween. That way they will be funny but still deal with 'scary' subjects if this makes sense? Read them dramatically to make your child interested and to make them laugh etc.

Yes brother, there is a very clear verse.

O ye who believe! let not one people deride another people, haply they may be better than they, nor let one group of women deride other women, haply they may be better than they. And do not defame your people nor call one another by nick-names. It is an evil thing to be called by bad name after having believed; and those who repent not, such are the wrongdoers. (49:11

Hope that helps.  Allah bless you.



love for all, hatred for none

<answer>



vulgar language and abusive behaviour are not clear terms, these are subjective terms. Quran is much more clear that what you expect.
 However, I have some here.

104:1 WOE unto every slanderer, fault-finder!
93:9 Therefore, the orphan shalt thou never wrong,



93:10 and him that seeks [thy] help shalt thou never chide
49:11 O ye who believe! Let not some men among you laugh at others: It may be that the (latter) are better than the (former): Nor let some women laugh at others: It may be that the (latter are better than the (former): Nor defame nor be sarcastic to each other, nor call each other by (offensive) nicknames: Ill-seeming is a name connoting wickedness, (to be used of one) after he has believed: And those who do not desist are (indeed) doing wrong. 
49:12 O ye who believe! Avoid suspicion as much (as possible): for suspicion in some cases is a sin: And spy not on each other behind their backs. Would any of you like to eat the flesh of his dead brother? Nay, ye would abhor it...But fear Allah. For Allah is Oft-Returning, Most Merciful.
23:3 Who avoid vain talk; 
25:72 Those who witness no falsehood, and, if they pass by futility, they pass by it with honourable (avoidance); 
28:55 And when they hear vain talk, they turn away therefrom and say: "To us our deeds, and to you yours; peace be to you: we seek not the ignorant."



However, it is more important to know what exactly you mean by abusive behaviour and vlgar language. Why do you prefer ambiguity over clarity?



</answer>

<answer>



yes
[4:148] GOD does not like the utterance of bad language, unless one is treated with gross injustice. GOD is Hearer, Knower.



[31:18-19] "You shall not treat the people with arrogance, nor shall you roam the earth proudly. GOD does not like the arrogant showoffs. "Walk humbly and lower your voice - the ugliest voice is the donkey's voice." 
[ 73:10] And remain steadfast in the face of their utterances, and disregard them in a nice manner.



49:11] O you who believe, no people shall ridicule other people, for they may be better than they. Nor shall any women ridicule other women, for they may be better than they. Nor shall you mock one another, or make fun of your names. Evil indeed is the reversion to wickedness after attaining faith. Anyone who does not repent after this, these are the transgressors.



[14:24-25] Do you not see that GOD has cited the example of the good word as a good tree whose root is firmly fixed, and its branches are high in the sky? It produces its crop every season, as designed by its Lord. GOD thus cites the examples for the people, that they may take heed.



[14:26] And the example of the bad word is that of a bad tree chopped at the soil level; it has no roots to keep it standing.



[41:34] Not equal is the good response and the bad response. You shall resort to the nicest possible response. Thus, the one who used to be your enemy, may become your best friend.

<question>



What is islamic calendar?



</question>



<answer from>



Lawrence of Arabia
Member since: 27 May 2006
Total points: 10347 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The Islamic calendar or Muslim calendar (also called the Hijri calendar) is a lunar calendar used to date events in many predominantly Muslim countries, and used by Muslims everywhere to determine the proper day on which to celebrate Islamic holy days. It is a lunar calendar having 12 lunar months in a year of about 354 days. Because this lunar year is about 11 days shorter than the solar year.

Islamic years are also called Hijra years because the first year was the year during which the Hijra occurred—Islamic prophet Muhammad's emigration from Mecca to Medina.



The Islamic months are named as follows:

Muharram محرّم (or Muḥarram al Ḥaram) 
Safar صفر (or Ṣafar al Muzaffar) 
Rabi' al-awwal (Rabī' I) ربيع الأول 
Rabi' al-thani (or Rabī' al Thānī, or Rabī' al-Akhir) (Rabī' II) ربيع الآخر أو ربيع الثاني 
Jumada al-awwal (Jumādā I) جمادى الاولى 
Jumada al-thani (or Jumādā al-akhir) (Jumādā II) جمادى الآخر أو جمادى الثاني 
Rajab رجب (or Rajab al Murajab) 
Sha'aban شعبان (or Sha'abān al Moazam) 
Ramadan رمضان (or Ramdān, long form: Ramaḍān al Mubarak) 
Shawwal شوّال (or Shawwal al Mukarram) 
Dhu al-Qi'dah ذو القعدة 
Dhu al-Hijjah ذو الحجة

For a very rough conversion, multiply the Islamic year number by 0.97, and then add 622 to get the Gregorian year number. An Islamic year will be entirely within a Gregorian year of the same number in the year 20874. The Islamic calendar year of 1429 occurs entirely within the Gregorian calendar year of 2008. Such years occur once every 33 or 34 Islamic years (32 or 33 Gregorian years)......It's a purely lunar calendar.



</answer>

<answer>



is a lunar calendar used to date events in many predominantly Muslim countries, and used by Muslims everywhere to determine the proper day on which to celebrate Islamic holy days. It is a lunar calendar having 12 lunar months in a year of about 354 days. Because this lunar year is about 11 days shorter than the solar year, Islamic holy days, although celebrated on fixed dates in their own calendar, usually shift 11 days earlier each successive solar year, such as a year of the Gregorian calendar. Islamic years are also called Hijra years because the first year was the year during which the Hijra occurred—Islamic prophet Muhammad's emigration from Mecca to Medina. Thus each numbered year is designated either H or AH, the latter being the initials of the Latin anno Hegirae (in the year of the Hijra).[1]



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_cal...



</answer>

It depends on where you live, I guess. If you live in a predominantly Muslim country, it's best to say "wa alaikum as-salam" because that would be the common type of greeting that everyone uses, be he Muslim or not.

If you live in a different country, then just use the most common type of greeting.

P.S. While as-salamu a'alaikum is the proper way to greet in Islam, it is not forbidden to be used by anyone else and if any non Muslim uses it we must accept and answer him with it and not even mention that he/she is not Muslim. So basically, I don't think you have a real problem.

Somehow I think you want to be agnostic not because you don't believe, rather because it's not cool to be Muslim these days.

<answer>



Just reply in kind. 
I am not a Muslim and I do not look  Muslim, I am West Indian and agnostic.  My office is across the road from a Muslim Association centre and they have prayers there every friday at lunchtime. Whenever the members of the community pass me on the street they greet me "Salaam Walaikum". I think it would be patronizing to repeat the words back not as it is not in my culture nor do I understand it, but I did feel honoured to be greeted in that way, i think it shows respect and how respectful and loving (real) muslims are.
I now feel even more honoured now that through the answers to this question I know the translation and next time I will reply in English 'Peace and blessing to you brother".
With you Knowing what it means I think you could reply with the appropriate response.  It shows you are returning the respect and brotherhood show to you, show you are respectful and confident in yourself.  That would not detract from you being agnostic, after all, its just a greeting, be polite and show goodwill, I am sure you will feel better for it.

<question>



Ramadan - can people still attend appointments etc?



I work for the DWP and I've had a few clients this week telling me they can't attend their appointments because its Ramadan.  I understood that things are supposed to carry on as normal in Ramadan (I'm not Muslim though so I might be wrong).

Can people still attend appointments etc during Ramadan?



</question>



<additional details>



DWP = Department for Works and Pensions in UK - Government body which is in charge of Welfare/Benefit claims etc.



They wouldn't have to eat/drink anything etc, some would need a medical examination for an IB claim but its not like a really invasive exam.



</additional details>



<answer from>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Of course you can attend appointments, work etc.
These people are being ridiculous.

If the appointment was right on the time of breaking the fast (about 7.30pm right now) this would be a bit awkward as understandably they would wish to eat and pray then, otherwise they should get out of bed and go to the appointment.

Muslims all over the world go about their normal daily lives while fasting.
Medical exams, including invasive exams, do not break the fast unless you have to swallow something by mouth or take a nutritional injection.



</answer>

<answer>



Even if somebody insists to call those 6 days, 24-hour periods, they can still be refuted by the fact that Qur'an mentions a day which is equal to 1000 years of what we count, and yet another day which is equivalent to 50,000 years of what we count, and hence, there is plenty of room to argue that those 6 days are not literal but rather 6 periods of a certain measure of time.



</answer>



<answer from>



Waqas
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 63 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The Qur'an states that "Allah created the heavens and the earth, and all that is between them, in six days" (7:54). While on the surface this might seem similar to the account related in the Bible, there are some important distinctions.

The verses that mention "six days" use the Arabic word "youm" (day). This word appears several other times in the Qur'an, each denoting a different measurement of time. In one case, the measure of a day is equated with 50,000 years (70:4), whereas another verse states that "a day in the sight of your Lord is like 1,000 years of your reckoning" (22:47). The word "youm" is thus understood, within the Qur'an, to be a long period of time -- an era or eon. Therefore, Muslims interpret the description of a "six day" creation as six distinct periods or eons. The length of these periods is not precisely defined, nor are the specific developments that took place during each period.

After completing the Creation, the Qur'an describes that Allah "settled Himself upon the Throne" (57:4) to oversee His work. A distinct point is made to counter the Biblical idea of a day of rest: "We created the heavens and the earth adn all that is between them in six days, nor did any sense of weariness touch Us" (50:38).

Allah is never "done" with His work, because the process of creation is ongoing. Each new child who is born, every seed that sprouts into a sapling, every new species that appears on earth, is part of the ongoing process of Allah's creation. "He it is Who created the heavens and the earth in six days, then established Himself on the Throne. He knows what enters within the heart of the earth, and what comes forth out of it, what comes down from heaven, and what mounts up to it. And He is with you wherever you may be. And Allah sees well all that you do" (57:4).

The Qur'anic account of creation is in line with modern scientific thought about the development of the universe and life on earth. Muslims acknowledge that life developed over a long period of time, but see Allah's power behind it all. Descriptions of creation in the Qur'an are set in context to remind the readers of Allah's majesty and wisdom.

"What is the matter with you, that you are not conscious of Allah's majesty, seeing that it is He Who has created you in diverse stages? See you not how Allah has created the seven heavens one above another, and made the moon a light in their midst, and made the sun as a (glorious) lamp? And Allah has produced you from the earth, growing (gradually)" (71:13-17).



</answer>

<answer>



The Quran in Surah 7:Verse 54, Surah 10: Verse 3, Surah 11: Verse 7, and Surah 25: Verse 59 clearly teaches us that God created "the heavens and the earth" in six days. The issue centres on the fact of whether these days are meant literally, or do they refer to God creating the universe over an indefinite period of time. Only God knows the expanse of time taken for His creation, bearing in mind time is highly relative, depending on the movements of the earth against the sun or even the moon.

From the prophet's tradition: God created the earth on Sunday and Monday. He created the mountains and the uses they possess on Tuesday. On Wednesday, He created trees, water, cities and the cultivated barren land. These are four (days). On Thursday, He created heaven. On Friday, He created the stars, the sun, the moon, and the angels, until three hours remained.



In the first of these three hours He created the terms (of human life), who would live and who would die. In the second, He cast harm upon everything that is useful for mankind. And in the third, (He created) Adam and had him dwell in Paradise. He commanded Iblis to prostrate himself before Adam, and He drove Adam out of Paradise at the end of the hour. The prophet's tradition not only states that the days of creation were literal, but that the heavens and the constellations were created after the earth!

So, it is anybody's guess as to the actual time taken as per our computation of time today, since the sun and the moon were created only on the 5th day that is Friday. As such how do you compute time without the sun and the moon? Wallahu'alam!



Source(s):



http://www.answering-islam.org/Shamoun/c...



</answer>

<question>



Is it allowed for a woman to be examined by a male gynaecologist?



For medical reasons? or does it have to be a done by a female doctor? what if there was no female doctor?



</question>



<answer from>



MuslimaH...
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 520 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



In the name of Allah, Most Compassionate, Most Merciful,

In the situation where a Muslim female is in need of medical treatment, the endeavour should be that she is treated by a female medical doctor, preferably a Muslim. If a female practitioner is:

a) Easily available,

b) One is satisfied and content with her medical treatment,

c) There is no other valid legal (shar'i) excuse for not resorting to her treatment,

then in such a case, it would not be permissible to seek the medication of a male doctor, rather, the illness must be treated by a qualified female doctor.

It is stated in al-Fatawa al-Hindiyya, a renowned Hanafi Fiqh reference:

"If a woman has a wound in a part of the body that is impermissible for a male to look at (m, meaning other than the face, hands & feet, for they are absolutely part of awra), it will be impermissible for her receive treatment from a male doctor, rather a female should be instructed to treat her. If a female expert is not available, neither is there a female who can be instructed to treat her… then in such a case it would be permitted for a male doctor to treat her, provided there is a genuine need. It will be necessary for her to cover other than the effected area, and he must lower his gaze as much as possible." (al-Fatawa al-Hindiyya, 5/330).

However, if the need is only for consultation or the medication is related to a part of the body that is not part of Awra, then it would be permissible to seek the treatment of a male doctor, although the treatment of a female doctor will still be preferable.

If the above-mentioned (3) points are not found, in that a medical female expert is not easily available, or if she is available, one is not content with her medication, or there is some other valid legal excuse, then in such a indispensable situation, it will be permissible to resort to the treatment of a male doctor, provided the male doctor only looks at (and handles) the effected area. The rest of the body of the female must remain covered.

Imam al-Haskafi (Allah have mercy on him) states:

"In the situation of a male doctor treating a female, he should only look at the effected area (m, whenever reasonably possible), for cases of need are restricted to the actual need. And it is preferable that the male doctor teaches and instructs a female in order to treat her, for looking (and treating) someone from the same gender is the lesser of two evils (m, i.e. when looking at parts of Awra)."

Imam Ibn Abidin (Allah have mercy on him) explains in his Radd al-Muhtar that, if the treatment is related to the private parts, then only in extreme situations will it be permitted for her to seek treatment of a male doctor. He states:

"If the treatment is on her private parts, then it is necessary that a female is instructed to treat her. If this is not possible and it is feared that the woman may perish or undergo unbearable pains, only then will it be permissible for a male to treat her." (See: Radd al-Muhtar ala al-Durr al-Mukhtar, 6/371).

The same has been mentioned in other Hanafi Fiqh references. See: Ibn Nujaym, Bahr al-Ra'iq, 8/192, Qadhikhan in his Fatawa, 3/409 & Bada'i al-Sana'i, 5/124.

Also, a Muslim doctor would be preferred over a non-Muslim for obvious reasons. However, if (once again) the three points are not met, then it would be permissible to seek the treatment of a non-Muslim doctor. Therefore the order in seeking medical treatment would be:

a) Muslim female doctor

b) Non-Muslim female doctor

c) Muslim male doctor

d) Non-Muslim male doctor

And in moving from one stage to another, the above three points should be kept in mind. The preference of a non-Muslim female doctor over a Muslim male doctor is due to the fact that, looking at the awra of someone from the same sex (as mentioned in Durr al-Mukhtar) is lesser of an evil. Also, the covering of one's nakedness in front of a (non-Mahram) male has been given more importance than covering in front of a non-Muslim female.

And Allah Knows Best

Muhammad ibn Adam al-Kawthari
Darul Iftaa, Leicester, UK
www.daruliftaa.org



</answer>

<answer>



Obviously, you are in the minority.  Waiting until November to do any thinking or planning or shopping decreases your choices dramatically.  For example, one of our friends is Dutch.  If his wife wanted to have items shipped here from the Netherlands so he could begin to teach their young children about Dutch traditions, waiting until November to place the order could mean that the shipment wouldn't even arrive at their home until after Christmas.



A lot of us plan for Christmas all year simply because our budgets are limited.  We have to buy gifts throughout the year in order to be able to give the people we love just the right gift.



And many more of us simply love Christmas and enjoy talking about it and planning for it.  Why should we be forced to limit our love and enjoyment to only the 8 weeks that you think are appropriate?

One of my best friends is a Halloween junkie.  She plans ALL YEAR for her Halloween costume.  Maybe she shouldn't be allowed to talk about her costume or shop for her props and materials until October?

If it bothers you so very much that other people love Christmas and enjoy talking about it and planning for it all year, then don't wander into Christmas forums or Christmas shops.  Avoiding us is really pretty easy.  We're not trying to gain converts or force anyone into doing their own year-round Christmas; we just want to do our planning with other people who love the holiday year-round as much as we do.



</answer>

<answer>



A diploma (or rather degree) can be your ticket into the corporate rat race.  A good or bad thing, depending on what angle you look at that.

IT, that's a tricky field in America.  It depends on what you can do.  I know many computer jobs, especially programming and tech support, are outsourced to countries like India, since the labour there is really cheap.  An American company can hire around 15 Indians for the price of 1 American.

I don't know where you are living but I assume you want to know about job availability and stability.  You should check out the want ads to see if there are many listings for what you do.  If there is it can be indicative that there is a demand for what you do where you live.

<answer>



Well, my friends the situation of Pakistan is quite complicated and is not simple as it may appear.

When Pakistan got independence from Britain, India was already under a large influence of Russia. Pakistan was VERY VERY poor, and it was being said that perhaps the country will not survive beyond 5 or 6 MONTHS (not even years). Pakistan did not get its share of wealth and the arms as per agreement with the British.

Pakistan at that time had no option but to opt for whatever was available. With India being favored by Russia, Pakistan went to the other pole of USA.



Later Pakistan grew a bit stronger due to the good skills of people and the fighting spirit. However politically Pakistan has ALWAYS been a huge failure. Democracy is like a poison to Pakistan. It kills it without a sound. The war of 1965 was a huge blow to Pakistan. Although Pakistan won the war by inflicting very heavy punishment to the much larger foe (India). But it gave Pakistan a very bad lesson. The USA backed out of the war and instead demanded Pakistan, that they should not use any of the USA weapons in the war against the attacker (India). Pakistan did not have any other weapons. As a result the USA inflicted embargoes on Pakistan. Then in 1971 we had an even brutal lesson. The USA kept on showing the carrot to us that the US support will be arriving through the sea, but it NEVER arrived.



Pakistani forces had learned the hard lessons. But !!!! there was hardly any other alternative. The Afghan war brought the much needed upgrades to the military and the Airforce. But as soon as the war was over, we were again subject to embargoes. And this time we did not even have the spares to keep the weapons operational. This time the experts vowed, that despite depleting and very low financial reserves we must shift our paradigm. Because we are dealing with a filthy whore (USA), and not a partner at all. As a result, there was a marked emphasis on self reliance and shift to other sources.



You might be wondering WHY? the Pakistani forces did take such a long time to take such a decision. Well the answer lies in the technicalities. I have worked for both the Nuclear as well as the defense industries. The USA weaponry is quite cheaper to the French and the British. The ratio in many cases is more than 1 to 2. Now compare all this to the enemy we have to deal with. We have India as our major opponent. With its defense budget that is routinely 6 to 8 times the budget of Pakistani forces. India buys the Russian weaponry which is not only good but also cheaper.



The military studies show, that in order to win a war, the attacker has to have a might of 3 times the defender. The Pakistani forces based their doctrine on the principle that we will not let India achieve this ratio of 1 to 3. As a result, being a smaller country (5 times smaller to India) u can see that we maintain a force of 0.45 million compared to Indians of 1.1 million. Just because we are not to let them have the ratio of 1:3.

Now take the same case, with a throat squeezing budget of less than 5 times the opponet, we have been trying to keep the ratio less than 1:3. This is a HUGE achievement. And it comes at a COST.

By 1990, Pakistani forces had started shifting reliance to Chinese sources, following the tracks of Nuclear industry. Our Nuclear is largely indigenous. However, the defense industry is much more sophisticated than Nuclear. The defense cannot shift overnight. Therefore, Pakistan shifted slowly towards the Chinese. With the downfall of the soviet, USA has grown into a big unchecked devil. Pakistan has been consulting the affairs closely and under the table with the Chinese. And it follows the policy both through the advisory body of NSC and the Chinese advisory.



At the moment, the Chinese don't want an upfront confrontation with USA. But time is approaching when the Chinese will be soon in the position to be a key player in the politics of world. The USA has been trying hard to knit a web around China i.e. making move to promote business in Mongolia (1995), building up in Taiwan and South Korea, and now strengthening India.

But let us see, where the world goes.

Pakistan is not in a position to be in a direct confrontation. We have a war reserve of only 35 days. We can fight a fierce war for 3-4 weeks, but perhaps we cannot sustain it beyond that period, without necessary supplies. And the routes of our supplies are NOT very open. We don't have the good relations with Iran. Also the adjacent province of Baluchistan does not have the infrastructure to facilitate rapid transportation (it is a difficult terrain). The Afghans are useless. The border with China is a very thin one and the most DIFFICULT land route. The reliable supplies can reach us ONLY either through Air or sea. And a major confrontation, would quickly seal off both.

It is a difficult situation.

However, the people to be blamed are the Pakistani Muslims, not anyone else.

The perfect Christmas holiday abroad?



My boyfriend and I have been discussing what to do for Christmas, and we would love to go away - either on a skiing holiday or sun!  We would go for a week from 26th/27th Dec, but skiing seems to be really expensive (more so than what it was a few years ago).

We have a decent enough budget, but don't want to miss out on having a good time, or settle for "budget" accommodation.



On the other hand, we would be happy to go for a week in the sun.

I just wondered what experiences people had had of Christmas/New Years holidays abroad?  What to look for when booking?  What to avoid, etc?  Any advice, recommendations or anything would be greatly appreciated!! Muchos gracias!!



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Well I live in Austria and know what it costs to Ski here. then Switzerland is even more expensive. But there are ways to beat that.
But you would need more than a few pounds. but you could just visit Vienna stay in one of the hostels like Vienna city hostel. travel to Semmering or some where else near rent a car or car share. and ski for the day Semmering is 95 Kms from Vienna and has a great ski area  and great ski rental and not to expensive for the day.(even though it was the host of the World cup Ski 2006-07) the roads are good. and you also have Slovakia near with cheaper Ski areas. Vienna is lovely around Christmas with more to see than most cities, great Christmas markets better than any in Germany. I just live 2 minutes away from the Vienna city Hostel if you need information, but won't be here at Christmas will be in Germany with my wife's family. Unless they come to Vienna for a change. They love it here but one week is to short to see Vienna and ski. but Vienna at Christmas is an experience not to be missed, as is New year here transport is all night new year and free



</answer>

<answer>



With Isha, you must pray 3 witr, it's wajib and Wajib is pretty close to Fardh. Your Isha prayer is not complete without praying Fardh.



"It is Mustahab (preferable) to delay the Esha Salaah to one third of the night. Rasulullah (صلى الله عليه وسلم) said “If I did not fear difficulty upon my Ummah, I would have commanded them to delay the Esha to one third of the night. It is Mubah (permissible) to delay Esha Salaah unto half of the night. To delay it to after half of the night is Makrooh (reprehensible) (Tahtaawi Page 184 Ilmiyya). "



Source(s):



http://www.askimam.org/fatwa/fatwa.php?a...

<answer>



Pork, that other white meat, has a bad biblical reputation. So are all of us pork-eating heathens on the express elevator to Hades or what?

Pork in the Bible/Torah/Koran has been condemned as unclean. Believers should not eat or even touch the carcass of a pig. Hence, the Target stores employees from Somalia requesting not to have to touch pork at the check out line. I am not going to berate anyone for his or her beliefs. This is a free country. Their qualms, caused me to think, why pork?

Pigs are omnivores meaning that they eat anything! They eat things many find disgusting and others find inconvenient. They eat, they survive and they live like pigs. Why do they live like pigs? Because they are treated as pigs. Pigs are actually clean and intelligent animals. A pig in a pigpen or sty chooses one corner of the pen for potty duties and the rest for the everyday things of pig life. It is up to the pig owner to clean out the poop if the sty is to be less sty-ish.

Pigs don't sweat, so they are into getting wet or hanging in the shade to cool down. Since few pigs can afford a swimming pool, they often have to opt for a mud bath. Elephants enjoy their mud baths if the pool is closed. So why are pigs picked on in religions?

Illness is the reason. Omnivores, especially outcast omnivores, eat things that can cause them to have parasites and other microscopic bugs that cause disease. Bears, horses, cats, dogs, and walruses can all contain parasites in their meat that can cause illness in the consumer that are in the same parasite groups as the pig. Okay cats, dogs and walruses are not omnivores, but they eat their entire prey. Think about it. Horses? That will have to be another discussion. Just about everything all critters that walk, fly or swim can have parasites harmful to humans.

<answer>



Non-Muslims and atheists will agree only if convinced through reason, logic and science. Eating of pork can cause no less than seventy different types of diseases. A person can have various helminthes like roundworm, pinworm, hookworm, etc. One of the most dangerous is Taenia Solium, which is in lay man’s terminology called tapeworm. It harbours in the intestine and is very long. Its ova i.e. eggs, enter the blood stream and can reach almost all the organs of the body. If it enters the brain it can cause memory loss. If it enters the heart it can cause heart attack, if it enters the eye it can cause blindness, if it enters the liver it can cause liver damage. It can damage almost all the organs of the body.



Another dangerous helminthes is Trichura Tichurasis. A common misconception about pork is that if it is cooked well, these ova die. In a research project undertaken in America, it was found that out of twenty-four people suffering from Trichura Tichurasis, twenty two had cooked the pork very well. This indicates that the ova present in the pork do not die under normal cooking temperature.



Pork has very little muscle building material and contains excess of fat. This fat gets deposited in the vessels and can cause hypertension and heart attack. It is not surprising that over 50% of Americans suffer from hypertension.



The Qur'an prohibits the consumption of pork in no less than 4 different places. Pork is also  prohibited in the Bible in the book of Deuteronomy and Leviticus.



</answer>

Well, we have to acknowledge that these livestock are just that -- live "stock."  This demonstates that a host of animals were taken from their native environs, then adapted with specific partiality for its domestic and business potentials and purposes, which is to say again that such was adapted as a medium through which monetary exchanges would occur.  There would be winners, there would be losers.



Someone above makes a good point -- if pigs are so filthy, then why not boycott KFC because of its Market in chickens?  And of course, there 'is' a case to be made as regards "domesticated" pigs, which should never have been made a staple in the first place...and so the varied scriptures were absolutely correct in that instance.



But none of the species of animals are in themselves the filth-ridden creatures in their native moorings and habitats; only is it so where Humankind has tampered with the natural balances of phenomena occurring in Nature. These beings live completely wild, otherwise clean, and vital lives, 'untouched' by the pestilential stench of greed as commonly akin to Western civilization.

'Domesticated' -- we should emphasize, 'domesticated' -- pigs were bred from out of a species of several types of family of swine.  There is nothing innately dark about the species of pig.  They are found in Africa and South America and Asia; the species the western world chose to domesticate and husband and therewith propogate are just one of a varied host, which has been extremely tampered with.  But none in the wild live in filth and whose intelligences are at a par with that of canines; some biologists say theirs are even more acute than that of canines'.



Oh they waddle in mud holes and that sort of thing, yes, but so do hippopatumuses, elephants, and rhinoceruses...  We simply never dare chose to market these species for eating and so never stigmatize them to be filthy creatures.  Moreover, they are too dangerous and powerful to dare domesticate for food purposes -- excepting "black markets," yes.  But that is a whole other matter, isn't it, which is a commentary on human beings, not pigs?

There 'are' species, of course, that are naturally prohibitive using -- whether for eating or otherwise -- because of their inherent natures.  These 'are' the vermin and vectors, which naturally are nature's own waste disposal species, salvagers, and re-cyclers...  Pigs 'can' be categorized in this light given the manner in which theirs has been tampered with.

Who does not know otherwise at least one of these types of species -- cockroaches, lice, countless forms of bacteria, buzzards, most but not all forms of mosquitoes, there are the rats -- even lobsters; that's right, lobsters! -- &c...&c...&c?



Lobsters, in fact, are quite a filthy creature that live to great ages, interestingly -- so important is their natural work upon the sea floors and oceans of the world to keep the waters and sea beds healthy.  They were never meant to be culled for dietary purposes.  Even native people only used and use them sparingly.  Same as to that of pigs.



But -- the Western world will have its ways: always are there the imbalances to be rent wherever the Western world comes to bear.  As to pigs, herein is the case that is so commonly focused upon: as regards the varied parasites and the like...direct result of tampering with the balances normally sustained in nature.



As to chickens, however, these are fowl native to Asia, and are not vectors or vermin, and are no different in their natures than are pheasant or turkey found anywhere.  They are foragers of vegetation and grains.  They are naturally a species that are spread out and do not cloister in cramped communities as we find in domesticated chicken farms and pig farms.

We need only view the conditions of certain sanitariums, nursing homes, and penitentiaries the world over to observe that when we put a cohort of any species of animals into cramped-up spaces, filth and disease are the result.



Many religions simply take in the habits of the pig based upon the artifices and conditions typically caused by haste and oversight of human beings and not those accorded these animals in and by nature.



Thus did a stigma form over time, and a mindset about pigs were established.  Second, the diets of olde were not healthy; and so, many of the leaders of the respective cultures and communities and religious groups thought it frugal to stigmatize pigs as a means to avert people from taking on imbalanced and unhealthy diets which practice includes the intake of too little diversity of grains, seeds, meats, vegetation, and assortments of varying proteins, without which balances starvation commences.



This is no different from that done in India many centuries ago: they made cows a sacred animal so that people would not slaughter these bovine creatures and cause certain imbalances in the environment, which in turn would cause an element of debauchery to take hold and express in the culture, for India's population had ever escalated over the ensuing decades and centuries.



As with too little of one thing and too much of another, poor nutrition would be a result of fixation upon some one thing, and thus an ineffective host of people, a weakened nation would ensue.

<answer from>



OnlyHumor RAJ
Member since: 04 August 2006
Total points: 634 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was thinking about the thought that thought and thinking are mental forms and processes, respectively ("thought" is both.) Thinking allows beings to model the world and to deal with it effectively according to their objectives, plans, ends and desires. Words referring to similar concepts and processes include cognition, sentience, consciousness, idea, and imagination. Thinking involves the cerebral manipulation of information, as when we form concepts, engage in problem solving, reason and make decisions. Thinking is a higher cognitive function and the analysis of thinking processes is part of cognitive psychologyThe basic mechanics of the human brain cells reflect a process of pattern matching or rather recognition. In a "moment of reflection", new situations and new experiences are judged against recalled ones and judgements are made. In order to make these judgements, the intellect maintains present experience and sorts relevant past experience. It does this while keeping present and past experience distinct and separate. The intellect can mix, match, merge, sift, and sort concepts, perceptions, and experience. This process is called reasoning. Logic is the science of reasoning. The awareness of this process of reasoning is access consciousness.



</answer>

pinky
Member since: 28 April 2008
Total points: 7010 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



"If one chooses not to marry or is unable to get married”



Islam is a flexible religion but has its boundaries; its flexibility allows one to adopt it as a way of life and implement its teachings into every situation; whereas its boundaries restrict man from becoming too engrossed into certain acts and therefore becoming extreme in following their desires. Flexibility and boundaries set by Islam have created a perfect balance for man to achieve good both in this world and the hereafter, it is a balance that allows man to be successful in both the worlds.

Marriage also has boundaries and flexibilities; it is a matter which has been regarded as half of one’s Imaan (religion). Marriage is taken seriously in Islam as it allows people to live in a clean and moral society where desires are fulfilled in a human and shameful manner. It is an act that increases the number of believers and will cause our beloved Prophet صلي الله عليه و سلم to be proud by having the largest number of believers.

The Prophet of Allah صلي الله عليه و سلم has clearly forbidden people from celibacy:



“There is no celibacy in Islam”

[Sahih al-Bukhari]

However, in life it is not always possible to adopt the Sunnah act of marriage. There come in life situations that restrict that do not allow one to get married.

Therefore, it is necessary to mention the ruling of marriage; is it Mustahab (desired/recommended), Sunnah (way of the Prophet صلي الله عليه و سلم, therefore encouraged), Wajib/Fardh (obligatory).

Similarly, there will be times when marriage will be ruled as Makrooh (disliked) or Haraam (forbidden).

At this time we will deal with those rulings that concern that person who chooses not to marry or does not have the means to.

According to Imams Abu Hanifah marriage is Sunnah and recommendatory. It is an act of worship and one should strive in fulfilling this act. However, if one is in a position where he cannot control his desires then it is Wajib (necessary) for such a person to get married as he will not be able to save himself from sinning.

However, a person is excused from marrying, so much so that he should refrain from it, if he does not possess the means of supporting his wife or the capability of fulfilling her rights.

The question remains for that person who wishes to marry but does not possess the means, what should he do? Hadhrat ‘Abdullah رضي الله عنه narrates that:



“We were with the Prophet صلي الله عليه و سلم while we were young and had no wealth whatsoever. So Allah’s Apostle صلي الله عليه و سلم said, “O young people! Whoever amongst you can marry, should marry, because it helps him lower his gaze and guard his modesty, and whoever is not able to marry, should fast, as fasting is a shield for him (from desires).”



[Sahih al-Bukhari]



In this Hadeeth it is clearly mentioned that one who cannot marry should fast as the fasting will act as a shield for him from his desires. However, whilst doing this one should make an effort to resolve the matters that are stopping him from marrying.

As a final note, it should be remembered that not being financially able and being in a position to provide for one’s wife means the basic essentials that are necessary. Having an elegant and extravagant wedding and inviting people is not part of ‘essentials’ and is in actual fact totally discouraged and forbidden in Islam. However, in today’s society we see people going to the extent of taking out loans to organise a ‘wedding to remember.



Source(s):



I Googled "Is it wrong if one chooses not to get married" and got this.

I hate long cut and paste posts like this.  I think I'll thumb myself down.



</answer>

<question>



Cutting Down at Christmas?



Me and my Partner want to cut prices for christmas, we want to buy a present for my sis & partner and my boyfriends sis & partner what can you buy for yound couple? and how to cut costs at christmas?



</question>



<answer from>



sunshine...
Member since: 25 April 2007
Total points: 8497 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



a friend of mine last year was totally broke, so made a box of christmas ginger biscuits which were tasty and personal!

if there's a group of you and you all want to cut down on costs, do a 'secret santa' with a price limit - get everyone to list a few things they'd like, then everyone buys one present and everyone gets something they want (instead of cheap stuff they don't)

<answer>



Make them a family cookbook, with all of your family's favorite recipes. You can do this online  I started one for my son, who wants it for his future wife (whom he hasn't yet met).  :)



allrecipes.com

$0.35/page for any additional pages.



That would be a great gift for couples! If you do this, inscribe it to them, & put brief family comments/memories on each page.  i.e.-"Joey loves this!"  or  "This was Aunt Ellen's recipe!"  They'll treasure it.



Click on Make-A-Cookbook on the left side of the page, toward the bottom.

If you like to cook, make that one special dish that only you make best!  Buy a new casserole dish to put it in for them to keep. Enclose the recipe in a Christmas card.  I make homemade strawberry jam in small jars for my loved ones.

When my mother passsed away 5 years ago in October, I made a copy of her engagement picture, framed it, & gave it to her sister for Christmas.  My mother looked so young and beautiful!

<question>



An Arab and a Paki Genie !!?



An Arab had spent many days crossing the desert without finding a source of water.He crawled through the sands, certain  when suddenly, he saw a shiny object sticking out of the sand several yards ahead of him.He crawled to the object, pulled it out of the sand, and discovered that he had a Manischewitz wine bottle. "Vell kid," said the Paki  genie, "you know how it voiks. Ya got 3 vishe!!
"Okay, I wish I were in a lush oasis, with plentiful food and drink."



** * * * * * * P O O F * * * * * * * * *



The Arab found himself in the most beautiful oasis he had ever seen and he was surrounded with jugs of wine and platters of delicacies.



"Okee-dokee kiddo, vat's your second vish?"



"My second wish is that I were rich beyond my wildest dreams."



** * * * * * P O O F * * * * * * * * *



The Arab found himself surrounded by treasure chests filled with rare old coins and precious gem !!



"Okay kid, you got just vone more vish. Better should make it a good vone!"



After thinking for a few minutes, the Arab says, "I wish that no matter where I go, beautiful women will always need and want me!"



** * * * * * * * P O O F * * * * * *



He was turned into a tampon.
THE MORAL OF THE STORY:



If you're an Arab doing business with a Paki  genie, there's going to be a string attached.

<answer>



I'll just copy and paste from my previous answer:



I've been asked this question a million times. This verse in the Quran makes it clear that there have been verses that were abrogated or caused to be forgotten and are replaced with something better or similar to it. Verse 2:106 in the Quran explains:



ماننسخ من اية او ننسها نات بخير منها او مثلها الم تعلم ان الله على كل شئ قدير



"We do not abrogate a verse or cause it to be forgotten except that We bring forth [one] better than it or similar to it. Do you not know that Allah is over all things competent?"



So the answer is, the Quran is complete. It was Allah's will that there be verses which were caused to be "abrogated" OR "forgotten" and replaced with something better OR similar. So verses were not abrogated, rather substituted.



</answer>

<question>



Ramadan Section:  Making up days for Ramadan?



I am making up the days that I missed for Ramadan.  Does it have to be done immediately and consecutively?  Or can it be done through out the next month as long as it is done?



</question>



<answer from>



Sarah Alholandia
Member since: 29 January 2008
Total points: 3644 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is better to do immidaitely, since you haven't got any 1% to be alive next day, let alone next month..



And above that, the fast of 6 days in shawwaal is like he fasted for his whole life.... But fard has to be done before sunnah fast..



</answer>



<answer from>



Surviving or Living?
Member since: 29 January 2007
Total points: 9065 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It can be done in any manner (not on Eid) as long as it is done before next Ramadan.
It is recommended that he hasten to make up that which he has missed during Ramadan so as to relieve himself of the responsibility. Likewise, it is recommended that he makes up for that which he missed by fasting consecutively because doing so is like having fasted as such during Ramadan.



</answer>

I agree with sis Sarah.

Lord's house:
God does NOT need a house. He has no human or creature needs. Why God appointed Kaaba as a focal point ? you will need to go back in history a little bit.



Ibrahim (Abraham) was a beloved servant / prophet of God. He stood up for Monotheism very firmly and he argued in favor of God. Thus God blessed him heavily. And GOD also Tested him thoroughly. He passed ALL his tests in flying colors and did not waver at all. Abraham ran into a problem between his two wives i.e. Hajra (Hager) and Sirai (Sarah).



Ultimately Abraham had to settle one wife (Hager) away from Sarah. At that point, God pointed out to him, the place where she and her child had to be settled. This was far away from Iraq, deep into the desert of Arabia, at the place of Kaaba. When Abraham settled them there, he prayed to God. There was NOTHING there. Not even a single plant, no water, no food. Abraham prayed to God there. And God took care of Hager and her son. Then God ordered Abraham to build a house of worship there as per his instructions (Kaaba). Abraham built it and again prayed that God may rush ALL the good things to this place. God promised that and thus we see that since Abraham 4500 years, the Kaaba continues a continuous flow of Muslims for pilgrimage (Hajj) and mini pilgrimage (Umrah). God blessed that land.



Thus God appointed it a sanctuary and a focal point to the billions of people who believe in him.



What is inside Kaaba:
There is hardly anything inside it. May be three or four wooden columns and a few other things.



It is also important to note that in the days of prophet Mohammad, God tested the believers in Mohammad, from a change in the focal point. Instead of facing the Kaaba, they were ordered to face Jerusalem for some time. That was to filter off those who would leave Mohammad out of Ego and not obey God's command.



Therefore, even for God, it is JUST a building and nothing more. However God has blessed the place in the sense that He has rushed every good thing to it. And God blesses people who visit it, by granting them their prayers and wishes.



--------
Kissing walking:
First there is NO religious rite of Kissing the black stone. There is no such requirement. This is something of a fabricated tradition and is being followed by many (not all) Muslims. It has no value.



Secondly: Walking:  This is what was prescribed since the days of Abraham and is followed the same way. During the walking and circumvation, the pilgrim Glorifies God and at the same time he may pray for ANYTHING he wants. God is simply glad to see the respect that the pilgrim gives to His "COMMAND" and "APPOINTED RITES".



God does not account for the physical movement. The real reward is for the OBEDIENCE to what He has decreed.



-----



The forms of feelings and qualities we have are a GRANT from God. Had he not made you kind hearted, you would have been a cruel person. Even the most kind hearted person cannot claim that it is his quality. "NO", it is a gift to him from God. All the goodness that we have is from God. And God himself is the MOST Merciful and Compassionate.



This worldly life and the Earth is a neutral zone for our test. There is an agreement between God and Satan. Because Satan claimed that he will take ALL of us away from the obedience of God. Under this agreement, God will not unviel himself to the people. And people will have to recognize him ONLY through the observation of signs etc.



Thus we see, that planet Earth contains everything to support life. It has stabilizers that balance out all that we do i.e. we produce CO2 and that gets consumed by plants. The water resource on Earth itself is a sign. The 24 hour rotation is sign. Earth has it and the nearest planetary satellite (Moon) does not have it. Earth has everything and Moon does not have those. The tilt of the axis of Earth and the revolution around sun, that gives it four seasons. This in itself is Unique to Earth. The Earth is just the right size and even the sun is JUST the right size. Had the sun been a little bigger, its spectrum would have been useless for plant life.



The punishing of evil and the rewarding of good, is also a manifest sign. You see the great empires of the past, where are they. As they turned evil, God wiped them out, even whent there seemed to be no possibility. The USSR is gone. Same will be the fate of USA and anyone who treads the path of evil.



These are ALL mercy of God. If he removes just any blessing from us, we cry on our knees, yet He provides us even if we do not knowingly thank Him. This is Compassion and Grace of God towards His creatures.

There is no reason to take this verse to mean that Jesus was saying that he and the Father make up “one God.” The phrase was a common one, and even today if someone used it, people would know exactly what he meant—he and his father are very much alike.
