<answer>



You can find many believers who will say, "The reason why scientific experiments fail to detect God is because God must remain hidden. He does not answer prayers if he knows that he will be detected."



In order to see the truth, you need to accept that this explanation is silly. If God must remain hidden, then he cannot answer any prayers. Any "answered prayer" would expose God.



The whole notion that "God" must remain "hidden" is a total cross-threading of religious doctrine. On the one hand, believers will say that "God wrote the Bible, God incarnated himself and died on the cross for us, and God answers millions of prayers on earth every day." Then in the next breath they will say, "God must remain hidden." God obviously cannot "remain hidden" and "incarnate himself." These two items are mutually exclusive. Therefore, the explanation that "God must remain hidden" is impossible. As soon as you accept how impossible it is, you can begin to see see that God is imaginary.



In order to see the truth, you need to accept the fact that the scientific evidence is accurate and irrefutable. We have scientifically proven that God does not answer any prayers on earth. Every single "answered prayer" is nothing more than a coincidence.



We can see reality by looking at a simple example. Imagine that the rate of remission for some particularly nasty type of cancer is 5%. That means that if 20 people get this type of cancer, it is almost always fatal. Only one in twenty of the people who get the disease will survive. Knowing this, you can see what happens if we actually analyze prayer:



20 believers contract the disease



All of them have read James 5:15, so all of them pray.



19 of them die



The one who lives proclaims, "I prayed to the Lord and the Lord answered my prayers! My disease is cured! It is a miracle! I KNEW God would answer my prayers!"



You never hear about the 19 who died. No one ever writes about them in a magazine. "Person prays, then dies" is not a great headline. And since they are dead, you will never hear from any of these people.



Therefore, if you don't look at all the facts around the "answered prayer," and you only hear about the one out of twenty prayers that succeed, it appears that prayer is successful.



The fact is, believers who pray die from this disease at exactly the same rate as people who do not.



We can see the reality of this situation simply by opening our eyes and looking at the data. But we do have to open our eyes -- We have to look at both the successes AND the failures of prayer to see the reality of our world. When we take a scientific approach and we do look at both sides, we see what is really happening.



</answer>

<answer>



Is she just adverse to entering a haunted house or dead set against it?



If she's dead set against it I'd say go with friends and leave her out.  In the end all you'll have accomplished is to tick her off that you "forced" her to go.  It's not worth it in the long run, and you'll have more fun without her there (with friends at least) than if you "make" her go.  Then again if she dragged you to the Sex and the City movie earlier this year (or similar event in the recent past or near future) she owes you if you haven't already cashed in on that.  ;)



If she's on the fence or able to be convinced head out to the bar first and have a few rounds (if you're of legal age).  Those things are always a little more trippy and fun with a little buzz going (ah-hem! being responsible adults in this case).  Plus a little jolt of adrenalin helps spice up and add a kick to other late night activities a bit when you get home!  ha-ha!

<answer>



There once was a boy called Johny. His mother asked him to go and buy some liver for dinner, and gave him some money.



Walking through town, he passed the toyshop and saw a toy boat that he had always wanted. And he could afford it...so he bought it. But now there was the problem of the liver. He walked around for a while, pondering...when he saw a strange creature asleep by the river. So Johny went over to it, got a sharp rock and gutted the creature, and pulled out the liver and took it home.



Later that night, he was in his room when he heard a voice:
"Johnyyyy, i'm coming to get you"
Frightened, he started looking around him room.
"Johnyyyy, i'm on the stairs"
and sure enough, he could hear creeking
"MUM!" johny cried! "MUM!"
"Just a minute dear, i'm a bit tied up at the moment..."she called back. she didn't understand.
"Johnyyyyy...I'm in the hallway"
Frantically, he started searching for something to use as a weapon. But there was nothing. Then, he saw the window, behind him.
"Johnyyy...i'm coming in"
The door started to creak open. there was no time for safety mats, ropes or second thoughts, he leapt out of the window...
"Johnyyyy...i'm underneath you!"



darkness.



"Johnyyyy...you're in my tummy!!!"



Source(s):



i was told this when i was 8 and it really freaked me out haha. Make sure you do the monsters lines in a sing song voice like Joooohnyyy im coming to geeeet youuuuu!



Enjoy!



</answer>

<question>



Need help tying a pirate's kerchief...?



I bought some fabric to make a kerchief for my 2 yr old daughters pirate costume.  How do i tie it?  Do i need to cut it to make those long tassle things on the end?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Fold it to make a wide triangle, then measure round your daughter's head and tie at the nape of her head.  The rest of the triangle will fall down behind and cover the knot.  She may not want to wear it for long so I wouldn't go to great trouble about it - 2 year olds, being two years olds.



</answer>

<answer>



Kids would HATE you.



There used to be this guy on my old street when I was a kid and he was SUPER rich....the kind of person you would expect to give everyone a king sized candy bar. The only problem was that he was also a dentist. So instead we all got healthy tooth packets with toothbrushes and dental floss and brushing guides LOL.



We all hated it because we wanted candy, but we all loved the guy and so every year we went back and got another toothbrush. He actually got so many regulars his wife started making personalized bags with our names on them, so that my brother could have a shark toothbrush and I could have the princess one.



So if you are well-liked in the neighborhood, you better have a lot of veggies because people will probably still return year after year.



I should probably add that I threw a few granola bars into our candy bowl this year. They were lying around, no one was eating them, so I'm hoping to unload them into unsuspecting treat bags.

<answer from>



young loveable huggable guy
Member since: 23 September 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



I believe Andre Gide is a modern author...maybe post-modern who lived during WWI and WW2 i think. When we learned about him in english i think  he was all for "Honesty is the best policy" and truth and stuff like that. So him saying something like that is not surprising.



Do you want an answer in Islamic terms or generally?



Heres my take on it. Everyone is searching for some truth in there lives. As humans we're always talking about "whats our purpose in life" and alot of philosophical things like that. If we can't find it then we pass the task down to our progeny to help find the truth. And basically the reason we are so desperate to try to find this truth is to explain some circumstance in our life or try to better understand the world we live in. Eventually, we will find this truth.



But let's work backwards here. Let's start with "Doubt those who find it," first. People who have found the truth, or they claim to have found the truth, be it scientifical, theological, philosophical...etc, they have always had criticism from someone else. This critic does not have to be a competitor in search of the truth of the same subject, but can be someone completely alien. Therefore the person who found the truth, will be getting criticisms of all "shapes, sizes, and colors." In a way, we are all critics, because as humans we have preferences, and based of those preferences we judge. But unfortunately, our preferences either so narrow or so selective, that we end up believing this truth...lol and now i am digressing.



Now, "Believe those who are seeking the truth." As you probably know, the dawn of the twentieth century was taken with very little confidence and much doubt and uncertainty. People had little hope of easily transitioning their perfect Romantic vision of the world into Modern World. Hence, we have someone as controversial or 'rebellious' as Andre Gide, himself, who wrote such pieces of literature having to do with this search of truth. If we were to believe those who are seeking the truth, then we would only believe them up until the point they have found the truth. Then we will start doubting them. Every great thinker, philosopher, scientist, some point in time has been doubter-only later proven to be correct or in position of great popularity or appraisal in the eyes of others. But look at us today we ended up believing them. But like i said, we are not critics. Critics on the other hand, are still seeking for the 'real' or 'better' truth than the great mind had come up with. Or, it could be for the other completely sane reason that the critic believed the truth could be acquired, only to realize that after it was discovered it was completely flawed.



Bottom line, those who are seeking the truth will end up getting the same crap as those who have already 'been there, done that.'



My take on this statement is, no matter how long we take or what we ultimately come up with as the 'universal truth,' we will always be criticized for what we believe is the truth. So this statement just turns out to be this circular irony, where Andre Gide, unintentionally, wanted us to question our motives and purpose rather than blindly follow one another. Much like you are doing with this quote and this quote is doing upon itself and others like me in a very eloquent way.



Source(s):

<answer>



With patience!



I have a degree in Theology, and the vast majority of people I meet have opinions on religion, but very little, if any, training.



Consider:  You went to Sunday School.  If your parents went to church regularly, you were there a maximum of 52 weeks in the year. However, many Sunday Schools do not run in the summer, and there are the "big feasts" (Christmas, Easter, etc), where the kids are in church for the whole service.  So, from say age 5-12 or so, you have 7x52x.5=182 - a maximum of 182 hours of instruction.



However - the Lectionary most churches use is a 3 year cycle.  This covers 25% of the NT, and 10% of the old one.  So, you get the same lessons every 3 years.



3x52x.5= 78 hours, that covers only a portion of the Bible, assuming all Sunday School lessons are tied to the lectionary - which they often aren't.



Now, Grade 1 has kids in school learning about 5 hours a day.  At that rate, if you went to a full-time Sunday School, you would be completely done all your religious training in about 15-16 weeks.  Which covers only a portion of what your religion is.  And, this is a best case scenario!



Imagine going to school from September until about Christmas, and then leaving school, and trying to live with what you had learned.  You could barely read (if at all), count, do math, or anything. Yet, this is the knowledge that the average Christian has - if they had done very well.  Most do not even have that.



So, for most people, they really know nothing about religion (as some of the answers to this question show!).  How can we be insulted when the person speaking knows nothing about what they are talking about?



This does offer us an opportunity to preach, or educate, or discuss what we know or believe, which is what I do.  However, many will not want to listen.  The faithful may know the Good News and want to share it; sadly, many do not want to listen.  But, getting mad won't help - just use gentle patience.



</answer>

<answer>



I try to correct their misconception.  If they are quoting scripture and making a mockery of it then I will explain the true meaning behind the scripture.  I get offended at times, but I have to stop and look to see if the negative statement appears as if it is intentionally meant to offend or if it is simply made out of a lack of knowledge and understanding. I don't feel my religion needs to be defended and many see that as me not caring about my religion, Jesus or God, but it is simply that Jesus and God don't need to be defended.  They are both perfectly capable of handing the situation without my interference.  Neither of them chose me to be the defender of Christianity and if someone insults my religion God will deal with them as He sees fit.



</answer>

<question>



Ramadan: Not knowing the value of something/someone until they are gone?



I love my parents more than anything in the world and respect them so much! If anyone were to ever even make a joke about them I would flipping rearrange their faces. Though, I feel like I've failed being a daughter. I wish I was obeying them more, providing for them more, and just make them happy and proud of me. I never feel as if I have done anything for them, my mother taking care of me when I was a child for one day isn't ever going to be equal to what I do for her for the rest of my life. My father and mother gave me the best gift, the gift of being raised in an Islamic environment where everyone outside of my home is the opposite of. My thanks go to Allah before anyone, then to my parents. I haven't seen my dad for about a month now (He's out of town) and I have been having the worst feeling of being a failure. I'm almost 19 years old and I have never truly appreciated what my parents have done for me. I want to make him and my mother the proudest parents ever! I'm going to graduate with a Bachelors very soon, I've wasted about 5 years in college getting nowhere. I've wasted my entire youth not keeping up with memorizing the Quran. I've wasted my life not treating my parents they way they deserve to be, and that's never possible. There is a Cambodian saying that my mom used to tell us, "A mother can take care of 10 children till they grow old, but 10 children can never take care of one mother while she is old". And it's true. It sickens me to see idiots go off about their parents and call them names!!! Are you kidding me? Even if your mother or father beat the living crap out of you, never allow yourself to say anything negative about them! People like those make me want to make their life miserable. Remember having a bad father or a bad mother is better than not having either. How can people have the nerves to say something bad about their parents? Because they didn't let them wear skimpy clothes outside, didn't let them get a belly pierce, don't let them hang out with their friends who influence them negatively, for shouting at them to clean? Heck. You people make me sick!



Allah grant my parents Jannat Alfirdous! I am making a promise to myself, from this day I will appreciate everything before it's gone, not just through words, but through action. Allah bless all the parents out there and give them happy healthy long lives. People need to appreciate their parents and respect them. Report this for all I care. At least I got this message across. Peace.



</question>

I completely understand how you're feeling. My parents have done so many things for me that I really don't know how to thank them. And I completely understand how you feel when you talk about people who get angry at their parents for no reason, such as "I want a belly piercing" or "I wanna stay out tonight past 1 am". God forgive me, I used to be like this and I'm so thankful to my parents that they never said "Yes". They always kept me on the right track. They never "gave up" on me.



Even when I nagged over and over, they still didn't abandon me. And you can't imagine how thankful I am! I swear to God. I thank my mother for confiscating my phone when I was bad, for taking away my computer when I spent too much time on it, for screaming at me when my room wasn't tidy. All the things that I was thought were unfair, were maybe the best things they ever did for me.



My sister's best friend, who's nearly in her thirties, once told me: "I have the best advice for you. So listen to me... Your parents are always right". I was shocked, so I asked why. She repeated: "They are always right. They know what's good for you. Even when you think they're unfair, they're just right." And I was really shocked to see how wise this piece of advice was. They have much more experience than me, and I should listen to them if I want to make it in this world.

<answer>



Last year I was a bag of jelly beans. It's easy and fast to make! You just get a dry cleaner bag you know the plastic bag thing that's over your clothes when you get them back. Then you cut out head and arm holes. Next you get a bunch of balloons and blow them up with air. then you put the bag on and stuff it full of the balloons. After that you tie up the bottom. Then make a sign that says jellybeans 25 cents and tape it to the front of your costume. Note: You will probably need to get someone to help you stuff and tie the bag. It's a really fun homemade costume!



Source(s):



I was this last year.



</answer>



<answer from>



Miss You
Member since: 21 July 2008
Total points: 230 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here are some ideas:



* Grab an old bed sheet nobody in your house cares about; cut eyeholes in it; and go as a ghost.



* Look through any old trunks and other clothing storage boxes you might have lying around your house. You might very well find some old clothes in there that you could use to make a decent Halloween costume.



* Check out your local thrift store. You should be able to find some good costumes for sale there for no more than a few dollars.



</answer>

<answer>



There are lots of things you can do with that! First, you could make your make-up very seductive with dark eyes. Then wear just any red shirt and black pants or skirt. Wear the cloak along with the horns and prongs. You could also be a witch and wear black tights/pantyhose (fishnets are great if you have them) black shoes, crazy socks, and whatever kind of outfit you want. Then put on the cloak and the witches hat. It'd be really awesome if you could paint your face green or wear green eyeshadow. Another option would be to wear the scary mask and dress all in black. You could also make it funny and dress up all girly, then put on the mask. Last, you could do something without all that stuff. You could put on a dress and heels and be a prom queen. Use a red marker or face paint on your face with dark makeup under your eyes and you can turn it into a dead prom queen.  You could dress in all white and be an angel or a ghost. You could even put on all sorts of mismatched clothes. Basically you can get away with almost anything! I hope that helped! And have a great Halloween!

<question>



Halloween safety precautions?



This is my first halloween trick or treating with my 16 month old and I'm wondering if anyone has suggestions on how to make it go smoothly and be safe.



</question>



<answer from>



keld2682
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 442 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Halloween is a time of mystery and fun. However, the nature of "Trick or Treating" requires parents and children to take extra precautions. Here are a few Halloween safety tips to help keep Halloween enjoyable and safe for everyone!



Children



Limit your trick-or-treating to your own neighborhood. Know where the unseen dangers are and avoid them.



Travel in groups. You will have more fun and there is safety in numbers.



Carry a flashlight with you if you plan to stay out after dark. Before you leave make sure the flashlight is in good working order.



Limit your visits to homes with the outside light on.



Never enter cars or homes of strangers -- even if they invite you in to get a treat.



Take your treats home and have a parent or responsible adult inspect them. Don't eat anything that looks suspicious or tampered with.



Costumes



Be highly visible to motorists. Wear light colored costumes that reflect light, or add reflective tape.



If you plan to wear a mask, cut the eye holes extra large to maximize vision, or better yet, wear stage make-up.



Be fire safe. Make certain your costume is flame resistant, and don't use lighted candles in your jack-o-lantern.



Trim your costume short enough to prevent tripping.



Don't carry sharp or pointed objects, even if they go well with your costume. You may injure yourself or another child.



Bags for collecting treats should be small enough to prevent tripping or obstructing vision.



Use comfortable shoes that fit properly. High heels or costume shoes that do not fit properly may injure you.



Parents



Have a pre-planned, well lit trick-or-treat route for your children to follow.



Escort your children or designate a responsible older child to accompany them while trick-or-treating.



Driving



Watch for children who may be distracted by Halloween festivities.



Turn on your headlights early and drive well below the posted speed limit.



Passing out treats



Give only commercially wrapped treats, coupons, gift certificates, or coins.



Leave your porch light on if you plan to participate in the festivities.



Prepare your children



Talk to your children about the safety rules they should always follow. Make sure you discuss what to do if they're approached by older children who want to harm them, about not talking to strangers, and where to use the restroom.



Remind children to:



* Never enter cars or homes of strangers -- even if they're invited in to receive a treat.



* Use the crosswalks when crossing the street.



* Wait for the proper signal.



* Look both ways before crossing.



* Watch out for cars turning at intersections or leaving and entering driveways.



* Never walk into the road between parked cars.



* Stay on the sidewalk.



Insist that treats be brought home for inspection. Separate suspicious items such as candies with loose or torn wrappings, unpackaged items, and items obviously tampered with. Any dangerous items discovered in the treats (razor blades, pins, etc.) Should be reported immediately to the police and kept for evidence.



After it's over



Calm you children down when the evening is over. Help them remove costumes and make-up. Sit down quietly and talk about the activities over a cup of cocoa or warm milk. If your child is frightened when going to bed, a lot of reassurance and a little night light goes a long way.



Alternatives



Look for advertised Halloween events and activities in the community as a possible alternative to going door to door.



Happy Halloween!



Source(s):



Halloween Safety Tips for children and adults



Happy Halloween



</answer>

<answer>



Notice how the girl in the picture looks like she's standing really really still....wonder if the crown fell off when she breathed?



Personally I would head out to the store a pick up a cheap headband. Then use tape or hot glue and attach the crown to the headband (heck you could use another headband to go around the inside of the crown to give it form as well). Another option would be to buy a cheap tiara from a thrift store or some place like Claire's, attach the crown to is and that way you can use it to keep the shape of the crown and use the combs of the tiara to keep in on your head. Also, if you're hair is long enough, you might want to put your hair up in a bun on top of your head and put the crown around it, then any way that you attach it will be concealed by your hair style.



</answer>

<answer from>



Boudicca
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 298 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



When I was growing up in the 1950s there was no such thing as Halloween, I guess it's an American import, made more popular by the horror film.
Neither the word Halloween or the date 31 October are mentioned in any Anglo-Saxon text indicating that it was just an ordinary day a thousand years ago.



From the Medieval period (1066 - 1485) through to the 19th century, there is no evidence that 31 October was anything else other than the eve of All Saints Day.



From the 19th Century to the present day, 31st October has increasingly acquired a reputation as a night on which ghost, witches, and fairies, are especially active.
In the year 835 AD the Roman Catholic Church made 1st November a church holiday to honour all the saints. Although it was a joyous holiday it was also the eve of All Souls Day, so in Medieval times it became customary to pray for the dead on this date.



Source(s):



Projectbritain.com



</answer>

<question>



Help I need another costume!?



I just got invited to another Halloween party that is on tomorrow night, since most of the people there tomorrow night will be there saturday night, i need a second costume, does anyone know a costume i could make from stuff i might have at home, i'm 18 average height

<answer from>



Maddie And Amelia
Member since: 19 October 2008
Total points: 299 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You could go as...



- A ZOMBIE - just use old, slightly frayed, baggy clothes, strips of material and lots of makeup!
- A WITCH - all you need is a black outfit, a cape (can be a trash-can liner!) and a hat (available from pretty much every store right now, or you might just have one lying around the house already!)
- BARBIE - tease your hair into a poofy style, wear lots of makeup and wear pink and white. Move stiffly as if you're made of plastic!
- A CELEBRITY - look through magazines and find a famous celebrity. Then, use your own makeup and clothes to mimic their style. (You might want to write their name on your shirt with fabric paint, to make sure everyone knows who you're meant to be!)
- A CHEERLEADER - easy: wear lots of makeup, a sports shirt, a short skirt, lots of makeup and your hair in pigtails. Carry pompoms! (You can easily make these, using strips of paper and an elastic band)



Source(s):



Hope I helped!



</answer>

None.  :(



I wish the kids trick-or-treated in this apartment complex, but none do.  It's so fun to see all the little excited kids in their darling costumes.  And older kids in their creative and gory ones.



We used to have cider and popcorn on our porch, with all our fold-out chairs for the weary to rest.  The neighbors would stop and chat.



I miss that.  I really enjoy handing out candy.  It's all in fun, and a good time!  :)



</answer>

1. Make some popcorn and watch totally scary movies in the dark or with candles.



2. Buy or Make an Ouija board and try to contact the dead.



3. Get a scary book or ghost stories online and tell them to your friend, in the candle light!



4. Find some magic spells online, take some candles and your spiritual powers and try to cast some magic.



5. Make some cupcakes and decorate them with orange icing and gummy worms (not spooky, just yummy).



6. Take a walk through a graveyard at night or any haunted places around your town.



7. Take a needle and thread, thread the needle and hold the thread over a piece of paper, that says Yes and No. Let the needle dangle, so it can circle or sway around. Then ask for spirits to guide it and ask questions. The needle should go to the yes or the no. Or... usually if it swings up and down thats a yes and if it swings in a circle, thats a no.
